# List of WWE United States Champions

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Baron_Corbin_WrestleMania_32_Axxess.jpg/220px-
Baron_Corbin_WrestleMania_32_Axxess.jpg)](/wiki/File:Baron_Corbin_WrestleMania_32_Axxess.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Baron_Corbin_WrestleMania_32_Axxess.jpg "Enlarge")

Current champion [Baron Corbin](/wiki/Baron_Corbin "Baron Corbin")

The [WWE United States Championship](/wiki/WWE_United_States_Championship "WWE
United States Championship") is a [professional
wrestling](/wiki/Professional_wrestling "Professional wrestling")
[championship](/wiki/Professional_wrestling_championship "Professional
wrestling championship") contested in the American
[promotion](/wiki/Professional_wrestling_promotion "Professional wrestling
promotion") [WWE](/wiki/WWE "WWE") on the [SmackDown](/wiki/WWE_SmackDown "WWE
SmackDown") [brand](/wiki/WWE_brand_extension "WWE brand extension"). It was
originally known as the NWA United States Heavyweight Championship and began
as a regional championship created by and defended in [Mid-Atlantic
Championship Wrestling](/wiki/Jim_Crockett_Promotions "Jim Crockett
Promotions"), run by [Jim Crockett, Jr.](/wiki/Jim_Crockett,_Jr. "Jim
Crockett, Jr.") [Harley Race](/wiki/Harley_Race "Harley Race") became the
inaugural champion on the title's introduction on January 1, 1975. [Turner
Broadcasting](/wiki/Turner_Broadcasting "Turner Broadcasting") bought the
company in November 1988 and renamed it [World Championship
Wrestling](/wiki/World_Championship_Wrestling "World Championship Wrestling")
(WCW) after its primary television program.

In March 2001, the then-WWF bought selected assets of WCW.[1] This resulted in
the WCW United States Heavyweight Championship becoming a championship for the
WWF, who referred to it as the WCW United States Championship. At [Survivor
Series](/wiki/Survivor_Series_\(2001\) "Survivor Series \(2001\)") in November
2001, the WCW United States and [WWF Intercontinental
Championships](/wiki/WWE_Intercontinental_Championship "WWE Intercontinental
Championship") were unified, resulting in the United States Championship being
deactivated. In July 2003, the title was reactivated as the WWE United States
Championship. Since the [2017 WWE Superstar Shake-
up](/wiki/2017_WWE_Superstar_Shake-up "2017 WWE Superstar Shake-up"), it is
exclusively contested on the SmackDown brand.

The championship is contested in [professional wrestling
matches](/wiki/Professional_wrestling_match_types "Professional wrestling
match types"), in which participants execute [scripted](/wiki/Screenplay
"Screenplay") finishes rather than contend in [direct
competition](/wiki/Sports_competition "Sports competition"). Some reigns were
held by champions using a [ring name](/wiki/Ring_name "Ring name"), while
others used their [real name](/wiki/Personal_name "Personal name"). As of
November 6, 2017, the current champion is [Baron Corbin](/wiki/Baron_Corbin
"Baron Corbin"), who is in his first reign.

Overall, there have been 87 different champions. [Ric Flair](/wiki/Ric_Flair
"Ric Flair") holds the record for having the most reigns at six,[2] while
[John Cena](/wiki/John_Cena "John Cena") holds the record for most reigns
under the WWE banner at five. [Lex Luger](/wiki/Lex_Luger "Lex Luger") holds
the record for longest reign, with his third reign lasting a total of 523
days, while [Dean Ambrose](/wiki/Dean_Ambrose "Dean Ambrose") holds the
longest reign under the WWE banner, at 351 days (overall the third longest in
the title's history).[3] Only two men, Lex Luger and [Rick
Rude](/wiki/Rick_Rude "Rick Rude"), have held the championship for a
continuous reign of one year (365 days) or more.

###
Names[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_WWE_United_States_Champions&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Names")]

Name[4][5] | Years[4][5]  
---|---  
NWA United States Heavyweight Championship (Mid-Atlantic version) | January 1, 1975 – January 27, 1981  
NWA United States Heavyweight Championship (Undisputed version) | January 27, 1981 – 1991  
WCW United States (Heavyweight) Championship | 1991 – 2001  
**WWE United States Championship** | 2003 – present
